item.title: France’s Finance Minister Is the Calm Hand Macron Needs Now
item.description: Eric Lombard is deploying his deal making skills to avert political turmoil
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Eric Lombard, France's finance minister, at the AI Action Summit in Paris, France, on Monday, Feb. 10, 2025. France is set to announce a total of €109 billion in investment in artificial intelligence projects in the country by companies, funds and other sources over the coming years, President Emmanuel Macron said on the eve of a two-day AI Action Summit.

item.title: Lula’s Star Appeal Is Fading in Brazil
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Travis Waldron

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, center, waves to the crowd at Planalto Palace in Brasilia after being sworn in as president in January 2023. Photographer: Arthur Menescal/Bloomberg

item.title: Investors Bank on No-Frills Pakistan Budget to Keep Rally Alive
item.description: Investors in Pakistan are hoping Tuesday’s budget stays focused on slashing spending, boosting revenues, and reinforcing the government’s commitment to its International Monetary Fund loan program.
item.dc:creator: Malavika Kaur Makol, Kamran Haider

item.title: China and US Holding Second Day of Trade Talks in London
item.description: The US and China resumed talks into a second day in London, with financial markets on edge as the world’s largest economies try to agree to allow exports of key tech and industrial goods and avoid escalating their trade war.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick on June 10.

item.title: Russia’s Crude Shipments Rebound With a Rare Delivery to Japan
item.description: Sanctioned tanker carries Sakhalin crude to Taiyo Oil’s Shikoku refinery
item.dc:creator: Julian Lee

media:content.media:description: Russia shipped 3.36 million barrels a day of crude in the four weeks to June 8 after a strong rebound in flows in the latest week.

item.title: Britain Loses 276,000 Jobs Since Reeves’ Tax-Raising Budget
item.description: UK employment plunged by the most in five years and wage growth slowed more than forecast, in the clearest sign yet that Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves’ budget was fueling a deterioration in the British jobs market.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Commuters climb the stairs to exit Liverpool Street railway station in London, UK.

item.title: South Korea Appoints Yeo as Trade Minister to Lead Talks With US
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung appointed Yeo Han-koo, a seasoned trade negotiator, as the new trade minister to guide the country through ongoing tariff talks with the US.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: Yeo Han-koo Photographer: Jean Chung/Bloomberg

item.title: From Visas to Jets, US and China Are Finding New Trade Leverage
item.description: Donald Trump brought many of the same grievances to his second trade war against China, but the economic battleground that’s emerged since then is making it harder to avoid a rupture this time around.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

item.title: Unrestrained Trump Turns to Military in Second-Term Power Play
item.description: President Donald Trump’s moves to deploy US troops to Los Angeles and hold a splashy parade on the Army’s 250th birthday fulfills his longtime goal of leaning on the military for a show of force and political power.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Courtney McBride, Jamie Tarabay

media:content.media:description: Tanks ahead of the US Army's 250th Anniversary Parade, in Mayland, on June 9.

item.title: Israel Takes Greta Thunberg and Aid Boat Crew Into Custody, Group Says
item.description: Israel said climate advocate Greta Thunberg has left the country on a flight to Sweden after the military intercepted an aid ship she was sailing on toward Gaza, where humanitarian agencies say a hunger crisis is unfolding.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Odenheimer, John Bowker

media:content.media:description: Greta Thunberg in a photo released by the Freedom Flotilla Coalition. Freedom Flotilla Coalition

item.title: Irish Government to Reform Rent Cap in Bid to Boost Home Supply
item.description: Ireland’s senior government ministers are set to approve new rental control reforms as part of efforts to tackle the country’s acute housing shortage by luring more apartment investors to the market.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

item.title: China Sends Two Aircraft Carriers Into Pacific Ocean in a First
item.description: Japan said it observed two Chinese aircraft carriers and supporting warships operating simultaneously near remote Japanese islands in the Pacific Ocean for the first time, a new demonstration of Beijing’s advancing naval capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Mari Kiyohara

media:content.media:description: The Shandong aircraft carrier at a naval port in Sanya in 2019. Photographer: Li Gang/Xinhua/Getty Images

item.title: Taiwan Indicts President’s Aide on Charge of Spying for China
item.description: Prosecutors in Taiwan have indicted two former officials, one of whom worked closely with the president, for leaking national security information to China, as Taipei pushes back against Beijing’s growing efforts to undermine the self-ruled democracy.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee

media:content.media:description: Lai Ching-te

item.title: US Deploys Marines to LA as Protests Spread to More Cities
item.description: The Trump administration escalated its response to anti-deportation protests in Los Angeles with the mobilization of 700 Marines, deploying active-duty military on the ground and increasing tensions with California officials.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, John Gittelsohn, Eliyahu Kamisher, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: Protesters gather along highway 101 during a demonstration in Los Angeles, on June 8.

item.title: Russia Unleashes Massive Drone Attack Against Kyiv and Odesa
item.description: Russia unleashed a sweeping drone attack on the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv and the Black Sea city of Odesa that left a trail of destruction as President Volodymyr Zelenskiy demanded increased pressure on Moscow to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: Photo released by Odesa Mayor Hennadiy Trukhanov of damage following an attack in Odesa on June 10.

item.title: Australia Names Wilkinson Treasury Head, First Woman in Role
item.description: Australia’s Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has named Jenny Wilkinson as the nation’s new secretary to the Treasury, making her the first woman to hold the bureaucracy’s top economic post.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: Jenny Wilkinson Department of Finance

item.title: Xi Urges South Korea’s Lee to Help Safeguard Free Trade
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping held his first phone conversation with South Korea’s newly elected President Lee Jae-myung and called for cooperation to safeguard multilateralism and free trade.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Lin Chen

media:content.media:description: South Korean flags fly in Seoul, South Korea, on Tuesday, Dec. 17, 2024. South Korea's Constitutional Court has started reviewing President Yoon Suk Yeol's impeachment case, while investigators reportedly plan to question him this week over his shock martial law declaration. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Says China ‘Not Easy’ as Trade Talks to Resume Tuesday
item.description: Trade talks between the US and China will continue into a second day, according to a US official, as the two sides look to ease tensions over shipments of technology and rare earth elements.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Tyler Kendall

item.title: Why Trump’s Deployment of Military in California Is So Controversial
item.description: President Donald Trump ordered the California National Guard on June 7 to dispatch at least 2,000 soldiers to the Los Angeles area as thousands of people demonstrating against immigration raids clashed with security forces. After vandalism and violence broke out, the Pentagon escalated the federal response by also mobilizing 700 active-duty Marines.
item.dc:creator: Peter Blumberg

media:content.media:description: National Guard soldiers stand outside the Edward R. Roybal Federal Building in Los Angeles, California, US, on Monday, June 9, 2025.

item.title: Albanese Slams Shooting of Australian Journalist at LA Protest
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has strongly condemned the shooting of an Australian journalist with a rubber bullet during protests in Los Angeles, describing footage of the incident as “horrific.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: Anthony Albanese Photographer: Hilary Wardhaugh/Bloomberg

item.title: Huawei Founder Waves Off Chip Curbs as Trade Talks Proceed
item.description: Huawei Technologies Co. founder Ren Zhengfei dismissed the impact of US export restrictions on China in a front-page People’s Daily article, wading into one of the key topics dogging Washington-Beijing trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Edwin Chan, Jessica Sui

media:content.media:description: Ren Zhengfei, founder and chief executive officer of Huawei Technologies Co., poses for a photograph following a Bloomberg Television interview at the company's headquarters in Shenzhen, China, on Friday, May 24, 2019. Ren, the billionaire founder of China's largest technology company, conceded that Trump administration export curbs will narrow a two-year lead Huawei had painstakingly built over rivals like Ericsson AB and Nokia Oyj. But the company will either ramp up its own chip supply or find alternatives to keep its edge in smartphones and 5G. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: White House Pitches Texas GOP on US House Redistricting Gambit
item.description: Members of Texas’ Republican congressional delegation met on Monday to discuss the prospect of redistricting to try and tilt the state further in the GOP’s favor before the 2026 midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: John Harney, Julie Fine

media:content.media:description: HOUSTON, TEXAS - NOVEMBER 02: Supporters listen from risers as Republican presidential candidate former U.S. President Donald Trump speaks during a campaign rally at the Trendsetter Engineering Inc. on November 02, 2023 in Houston, Texas. Former President Trump's visit to Houston marks his second stop in Texas since earlier this year. The visit comes as his sons Don Jr. and Eric testified at his civil fraud in New York trial today. Trump may be forced to sell off his properties after a judge ruled that he committed fraud for years while building his real estate empire. (Photo by Brandon Bell/Getty Images)

item.title: Saudi Arabian Crown Prince MBS Gets G-7 Invitation From Canada
item.description: Canada has invited Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to attend the Group of Seven summit, according to a person familiar with the matter, in another sign of a new approach to foreign policy under Prime Minister Mark Carney.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: Mohammed bin Salman Photographer: Prakash Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s Ishiba Pledges 50% Pay Rise by 2040 Ahead of Elections
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has set pay raises and a ¥1 quadrillion ($6.9 trillion) economy as the top campaign promises for this summer’s upper house election, as the date nears for voters to give their latest verdict on his administration.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: California Asks Court to Halt Trump Deploying Military in LA
item.description: California asked a federal court to halt the Trump administration’s “illegal” deployment of the state’s National Guard and the US Marines in Los Angeles to quell unrest over the president’s immigration raids.
item.dc:creator: Malathi Nayak, Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: LAPD officers and National Guard soldiers on patrol as demonstrators protest outside a downtown jail in Los Angeles, on June 8.

item.title: Ireland Needs Fiscal Rule as Economic Risk Grows, Watchdog Warns
item.description: The Irish government should commit to a domestic fiscal rule so it can better plan spending as the economy enters uncertain territory, the state’s fiscal watchdog warned.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: Sunrise over the River Liffey in Dublin, Ireland, on Friday, Nov. 22, 2024. Ireland's election will be a big test of how the country handles its cash surplus. Photographer: Paulo Nunes dos Santos/Bloomberg

item.title: Pentagon Sends 700 Marines to Los Angeles, Escalating Response to Protests
item.description: The Trump administration is sending about 700 active duty Marines to reinforce the National Guard in response to protests in Los Angeles, the US Northern Command said Monday of a move continuing an escalation that California officials have called unwarranted.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: Protesters stand on a vandalized vehicle during a demonstration in Los Angeles, on June 8.

item.title: California Sues Trump to Protect Its Transgender Athletes Policy
item.description: California sued to protect itself from the Trump administration’s threats to pull federal funding over a state law that allows transgender high school athletes to compete in female sports, the latest showdown between President Donald Trump and the most populous state.
item.dc:creator: Malathi Nayak

media:content.media:description: A demonstrator holds a transgender pride flag during a President’s Day protest near the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, Feb. 17, 2025. Thousands of probationary employees in multiple government agencies are facing dismissal as the Trump administration continued its effort to rapidly thin the ranks of federal workers. Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: US Asks Appeals Court to Let Trump Tariffs Remain for Longer
item.description: A federal appeals court is closer to ruling on whether to keep most of President Donald Trump’s global tariffs in place longer while the legal battle over them continues.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: A container ship at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles, California, US, on Friday, April 4, 2025. President Donald Trump blasted China for retaliating against his sweeping tariff plan and vowed his economic policies will never change, as the prospect of a trade war wreaked more havoc on the global economy.

item.title: France’s Macron Doesn’t Rule Out Calling Snap Elections Again
item.description: French president Emmanuel Macron said he doesn’t rule out the possibility of again dissolving the National Assembly and calling snap elections.
item.dc:creator: Samy Adghirni, Ania Nussbaum

media:content.media:description: France’s President Emmanuel Macron speaks during the United Nations Ocean Conference in Nice, France, on June 9.
